item.title: JRPGs That Have Absurd Stories
item.description:
Summary

  • Some JRPGs, like Akiba's Trip and Kingdom Hearts, have wacky and hard-to-follow plots.
  • Final Fantasy 7 Remake adds confusion with new elements like Whispers, impacting the original plot of Midgar.
  • Games like Pokemon Conquest offer bizarre premises, blending different franchises in strange ways.

It's safe to say that a lot of games from Japan have wacky stories, from Metal Gear to something truly wild like Deadly Premonition . Absurd plots do not mean the overall narratives are bad. They can just be hard to follow or may not be recommended for those who don't have the palate for the weirdness of Japan.

This is why anime is not widely accepted by a lot of people in the West, who still think their stories are hard to follow. Back on the topic of games, JRPGs , especially, have some of the strangest plots out there. Without a guidebook, it can be hard to know what's going on, but fans still love these games.

There will be some story spoilers.

Akiba's Trip: Undead & Undressed

Strip Teasing Vampires

  • Developer : Acquire
  • Publisher : Xseed Games (NA)
  • Released : August 12, 2014 (NA)
  • Platforms : PS3, PS Vita, PS4, PC

Games that try to add to the lore of vampires in a clever new way should be celebrated, and there’s no zanier vampire plot than Akiba's Trip: Undead & Undressed , which does exactly that.

Vampire-like beings are cropping up in Japan, genetically modified to be extremely powerful but still sensitive to light. To destroy them, players have to damage their clothes in battle, thus exposing them to the sun and obliterating them from existence. The wackiness of the narrative has a very heavy anime vibe with plenty of risqué fan service amidst all the clothes-ripping action.

Eternal Sonata

A Composer’s Dream

Eternal Sonata
JRPG
Systems
Released
September 17, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Fantasy Violence, Mild Language, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

Classical music enthusiasts will recognize the name of Frédéric Chopin, a Polish composer who lived in the 1800s. Eternal Sonata imagines Chopin living out his dying days in a fantastical world of anime characters and monsters found within his dreams.

Everything and everyone has a melodic twist to their name, like Beat and Jazz, who are allies. Normally, someone from the 1800s, like Chopin, should be startled by what they witness, but Chopin is cool as can be, which might be the strangest thing about the story.

Final Fantasy 7 Remake

Whisper Of The Heart

Final Fantasy 7 Remake
12
8.4 /10
Released
April 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen due to Language, Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco, Violence
Powered by

Final Fantasy 7 Remak e covers a very small portion of the original game, Midgar, and the story is then continued in Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth . Final Fantasy 7 already had a confusing plot to follow on the PS1, but this was magnified in the remake thanks to the addition of Whispers.

Ghost-like entities called Whispers appear to stop Cloud and the others from altering events that happened in the original game. Not everyone can see them, and even though they are trying to prevent the timeline from changing, the story still plays out differently from the original Midgar chapter. The full power of the Whispers isn’t even fully explored in this game, and they do not appear in a large capacity within Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth either, which is odd.

Kingdom Hearts Re:Coded

Digital Doubles

Kingdom Hearts Re:Coded
Action RPG
Systems
7.0 /10
Released
January 11, 2011
ESRB
Everyone 10+ // Fantasy Violence

Powered by

The first Kingdom Hearts began simply enough compared to other entries. It's a crossover game between Disney and Final Fantasy characters, mixed in with original characters, too. Sora gets a magical Keyblade, travels around with Donald and Goofy, and then seals Keyholes in each Disney world to prevent monsters, called Heartless, from causing havoc.

It was the sequels that cranked up the oddness, and Kingdom Hearts Re:Coded is the hardest to follow of the bunch. Players have to go through digitally archived worlds to destroy data clusters as a debug version of Sora. Doing so helps the digital worlds become full and unlocks memories for Sora, and that’s just a very surface-level explanation.

Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii

Pirates, In This Day And Age?

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii
7.3 /10
Released
February 21, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood, Intense Violence, Partial Nudity, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

The Yakuza/Like a Dragon series is known for having weird side quests but ultimately grounded main dramatic narratives. The same cannot be said about the latest spinoff, Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii , which finds longtime anti-hero Goro Majima with amnesia.

To get his memories back, Majima reluctantly becomes a pirate captain and sails the seas around Hawaii in an old-school pirate galleon. Other pirates are hanging out around the islands as well, with similar ships and costumes. This is a modern-day game with swashbuckling and treasure, so it’s a bit hard to follow, but it's ultimately a good time.

Pokemon Conquest

Conquer Feudal Japan With Pokemon

Pokemon Conquest
Tactical
RPG
Systems
Released
June 18, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
E For Everyone due to Mild Cartoon Violence, Mild Suggestive Themes
Powered by

Pokemon Conquest is a great tactical RPG with a funny, albeit weird, premise. It's a crossover between the Pokemon series and the Nobunaga’s Ambition strategy series, wherein samurai lords use Pokemon to wage war all across Japan.

It’s odd to consider samurai sitting back while they let monsters do their fighting for them, especially the infamous Nobunaga Oda. This may be why Pokemon Conquest didn’t become as popular on the DS as some other Pokemon games and tactical RPGs did, but it remains a fun little curio for those willing to dig it up.

Project X Zone

Fan Service First, Ask Questions Later

Project X Zone
Tactical RPG
Systems
Released
October 11, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
t
Powered by

Project X Zone has an even wilder premise than Pokemon Conquest and Kingdom Hearts combined. It’s a crossover between Sega, Bandai Namco, and Capcom characters. A game that just crossed over Capcom characters into a tactical RPG would be strange enough, let alone adding two other giant publishers into the mix.

There’s a vague setup involving multidimensional rifts opening up, which is how monsters and villains from other universes are appearing on Earth. Seeing Resident Evil and Tekken characters interact is strange beyond words, and that’s only one example. It’s a game about fan service, with the story feeling like an afterthought and just a way to bridge these properties together.

Xenosaga

JRPG Stands For Jesus Role-Playing Game

Xenosaga Episode I: Der Wille zur Macht
JRPG
Systems
Released
February 25, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood and Gore, Violence
Powered by

All of the Xeno games have funky stories, but the Xenosaga trilogy on the PS2 has, by far, the wildest. It all begins in Xenosaga Episode 1: Der Wille zur Macht, with mankind discovering a monolith known as the Zohar. Then, the story rushes ahead thousands of years into space, where colonial marines are trying to fight an invisible alien force.

There are robots, cyborgs, angels, and other cosmic entities all connected by a vague religious background. By the end, it seems like Jesus was involved, somehow. Again, it’s a hard one to parse, even with its lengthy cutscenes, and part of the reason why so many things were left unsaid is that the series was intended to be six games.

item.title: Black Ops 6: All Reckoning Zombie Intel Locations
item.description:
Black Ops 6 has released the final Zombies map, Reckoning, and within the map, there are plenty of secrets to uncover. Most of these secrets are fun easter eggs, but there are others for the collectors out there with the classic Zombie Intel system for further lore. There are 13 Audio Logs, 7 Documents, and 5 Artifacts in Reckoning, and we've compiled all Zombie Intel in Reckoning below to make the hunt all too easy.

All Audio Logs in Reckoning (13/13)

Audio Log #1 – Mom Genes

Activate the secret room above the T1 Mutant Research Test Area by solving the periodic table puzzle for the Gorgofex easter egg. This can be done by looking at the static terminals in the T1 Mutant Research Lab by Deadshot Daiquri and the terminal by Richtofen's family in T1 Mutant Research Test Area, and then combining the first letter of each word to find the element on the periodic table to use the atomic number of said element as the password. In the southeast corner of the T1 Bioweapons Lab, players can grab this Audio Log.

Audio Log #2 – Play to Win

From spawn, head left to the elevator that leads to the T1 Quantum Computing Core, then open the door to enter the T1 Quantum Computing Lab. Inside the T1 Quantum Computing Lab, look to the southeast corner to find a bunch of computers and a chair, which holds this Audio Log.

Audio Log #3 – The Things I've Seen pt 1

Inside the T1 Mutant Research Test Area, players can find this Audio Log sitting on a crate just by the shooting range on the south side, before leaving for the launchpad to the T2 Android Assembly.

Audio Log #4 – The Things I've Seen pt 2

Reach the T1 Director's Office from the T2 Dark Entity Containment launchpad, and then, once in Richtofen's office, look to teh wooden shelves at the southwest wall. To the right of the coffee machine, players will be able to spot this Audio Log.

Audio Log #5 – Reactive pt 1

Reach the T1 Executive Suite by using the launchpad at the T2 Dark Entity Containment area, and then head into the room which holds the Tsarkov 7.62 wall buy. To the left of this wall buy, and on the shelf by the TV on the wall, is this Audio Log.

Audio Log #6 – Reactive pt 2

Head into the Pack-a-Punch room of T2 Sublevel 10 from the portal in the Director's Office, and look to the north wall. Players will be able to see a crashed elevator shaft. Approach the elevator shaft, and when anti-gravity is enabled, jump up and interact with the top of the elevator to grab this Audio Log.

Audio Log #7 – Reactive pt 3

Head inside the T2 Android Assembly, where on the northeast wall, there is a bunch of shelves. This is in the same room as the android conveyor belt, and within the right-most shelf, second up, is the Audio Log.

Audio Log #8 – Great Voice From Beyond

Players need to complete the main easter egg steps and reach the final boss fight, either against S.A.M. or Richtofen, to reach the T3 Rooftop. Once players are on the T3 Rooftop during the boss fight, they can head to the southwest wall where there's a workstation that holds the Great Voice From Beyond recording. This is the only Zombie Intel in Reckoning that requires players to essentially complete the main easter egg.

Audio Log #9 – The Forespoken

Inside T2 Dark Entity Containment, players can head to the right of Stamin-Up and look at the right side of the Forsaken's containment box. On the southeast side, players can find a forklift, where on the seat is the Audio Log.

Audio Log #10 – Dysphoria

Unlock the secret T2 Teleportation Lab room by acquiring the Syringe from the centrifuge by the Mangler in T1 Mutant Research Lab, then head to the Pack-a-Punch room and enter the Particle Accelerator to become an orb. In this orb form, hit into the floating zombie, and then interact with it for the Blood Sample. Take the Blood Sample back to the centrifuge and kill the Mangler for the Fowler-Mutant Injection, then head to the T2 Dark Entity Containment at the southeast wall upstairs, where you can interact with an ID scanner and activate the Fowler-Mutant Injection to open the secret room. Inside, at a terminal in the northwest area, is this Audio Log.

Audio Log #11 – Miracle Worker

From spawn, head down to the main reception desk in T1 Project Janus Reception. Behind the desk on the left surface, players can grab the Audio Log.

Audio Log #12 – Whistleblower

For this Audio Log, your Operator must be Weaver . When playing Reckoning as Weaver, enter the T1 Mutant Research Test Area where Richtofen's family is in a giant cloning vat. Doing so after Round 13 (or Round 20) will trigger an audio line from S.A.M. Players can now interact with a terminal at the west wall to spawn in this Audio Log.

Audio Log #13 – ???

This Audio Log remains unfound, with the only hint being "safe and sound". It's theorized that you need the Mister Peeks Field Upgrade, which is not currently in-game.

All Documents in Reckoning (7/7)

Document #1 – I'm a Real Girl

Inside the T1 Project Janus Reception and T1 Executive Suite, players can find a bunch of trash cans. Interact with the trash cans until you get loot drops from 4 of them. After 4 successful lootings, head to the trash can at the south wall of spawn, which is now glowing gold, to find this Document inside.

Document #2 –​​​​​​​ Employee of the Month

Inside the T1 Director's Office, players can find a projector that shows blueprints on a wall. Jump and interact with the projector to drop this Document.

Document #3 – Department Head

Head into the T1 Mutant Research Lab, and look down the hole in the ground. Jump into the hole and parachute, while immediately drifting to the right to find a ledge that contains a Dark Aether plant. Hug this wall as you parachute down to collect this Document.

Document #4 – Mangler Matrix

In the T1 Mutant Research Lab, take the crumbled stairs up to the platform where a bunch of Acid Zombies are in vats. Follow this walkway to the very end and look underneath the lab equipment at the northeast wall to find a pile of papers. Shoot these papers to reveal this Document.

Document #5 – Safety Measures

At the northwest wall of T2 Android Assembly, players will find 3 deactivated Kommando Klaus bots in a line. The back Klaus is holding a briefcase, which can be shot to drop this Document.

Document #6 – ???

This Document's only hint is "Safe and Sound", and has not currently been solved. We believe it's for the Mister Peeks Field Upgrade, which is not currently in-game.

Document #7 –​​​​​​​ ???

This Document's only hint is "Pole Vault", and has not currently been solved. We'll update with the answer as soon as we find it.

All Artifacts in Reckoning (5/5)

Artifact #1 – Knick Knack

Head inside the T1 Director's Office and interact with the snowglobe on the desk, which will provide players with this artifact and the way into Sublevel 10 for the Pack-a-Punch.

Artifact #2 – Klaus Arm

On a special Max Ammo round, shoot off the arm of a Kommando Klaus and then kill them for their arm to drop. Simply pick up the arm to get this Artifact.

Artifact #3 – Gorgofex

Acquire the Gorgofex, the Reckoning's Wonder Weapon. This detailed guide will help players through the lengthy steps.

Artifact #4 – Fungal Head

With the Gorgofex, use a charged shot at the north wall in the T1 Quantum Computing Core. The correct spot to fire is at the open window, which contains a zombie, a white ceiling light, and a Dark Aether plant. This will drop the Fungal Head, which can be picked up.

Artifact #5 – Wish You Were Here

Inside the T2 Dark Entity Containment room, use the Caster Turret trap that's closest to Stamin-Up, on the left side of the open doors. Then, get it to hit a zombie by standing by the pile of trash next to an electric pillar at the south terminal, for this Artifact to appear.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: 5 Xbox Game Pass Games to Play This Week (August 10 - August 16)
item.description:
August is shaping up to be one of the more exciting months on Xbox Game Pass in 2025, with a mix of surprise arrivals, high-profile titles, and soon-to-depart favorites. From retro shooter royalty to cinematic blockbusters, this week’s lineup covers nearly every kind of gaming mood. There are reasons to jump in now, whether it’s capitalizing on QuakeCon buzz, catching something before it leaves, or getting in on a hotly discussed title while the conversation is still going strong. And to think that this list doesn’t even include upcoming titles on Game Pass is proof that the platform’s momentum will stay strong and steady throughout the rest of the year.

These recommendations aren’t just about what’s new, but about timing. Some games here are riding waves of community turnout, others are primed to reintroduce familiar faces within their franchise, and a few are simply too historically important to pass up. Whether a player is carving through demons, navigating political conspiracies, or losing hours in social sim perfection, there are plenty of games on Xbox Game Pass to keep your week booked solid.

Heretic + Hexen

Game Pass surprises are rare, but Heretic + Hexen ’s shadow drop on Xbox Game Pass is exactly the kind of drop that makes the subscription so exciting. This enhanced 2-in-1 collection resurrects two cult-classic shooters from 1994 and 1995 that helped shape the FPS genre as players know it. Heretic and Hexen introduced inventory systems, vertical aiming, and expanded the formula with distinct character classes and branching level design. This updated release doesn’t just preserve these games’ legacy, but it makes them more accessible than ever with broader platform support, better controls, and language options that welcome a whole new generation of players.

In Heretic , players step into the boots of Corvus as he battles to overthrow the Serpent Rider D’Sparil. Hexen moves the action to the dark realm of Cronos, where the warlord Korax threatens to plunge the world into chaos. With three unique classes, players carve their own path through the campaign’s twisted environments and puzzles, culminating in an epic showdown with Korax himself.

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Heretic + Hexen
FPS
Action
Adventure
Systems
Released
August 7, 2025
ESRB
T For Teen // Blood and Gore, Violence
Developer(s)
id Software, NightDive Studios
Publisher(s)
Bethesda
Steam Deck Compatibility
Verified

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Step into the definitive re-release of two dark spell-casting shooters that shaped the genre.

Forged by Raven Software on a modified DOOM engine, Heretic and Hexen were released in 1994 and 1995, pushing first-person shooters into bold new territory. These innovative cult classics introduced groundbreaking features like inventory systems, vertical aiming, and distinct character classes, reshaping first-person action games for generations to come. This enhanced restoration makes Heretic + Hexen available to new audiences and long-time fans with expanded accessibility across more platforms and languages than ever before. Whether you're returning to these shadowy realms or discovering them for the first time, an epic legacy awaits.


Owners Receive
Heretic: Shadow of the Serpent Riders¹

Hexen: Beyond Heretic¹

Hexen: Deathkings of the Dark Citadel¹

Two all-new episodes created in collaboration between individuals at id Software + Nightdive Studios:

Heretic: Faith Renewed

Hexen: Vestiges of Grandeur

There are a total of 117 campaign maps and 120 deathmatch maps in Heretic + Hexen.

New Enhancements
Online cross-platform deathmatch and co-op for up to 16 players²

Local split-screen deathmatch and co-op for up to 8 players

Toggleable, enhanced Tome of Power soundtrack by Andrew Hulshult

Community-published mod support with an in-game mod browser² ³

Improved performance with multithreaded rendering supporting up to 4K resolution and 120 FPS⁵

A Vault section containing concept art and unused sprites from the development of the original games

Accessibility options, such as updated UI, improved legibility, contrast and screen FX adjustments, and text-to-speech features.

Modern controller support

Weapon carousel for faster weapon switching

Game balance toggle (original/enhanced)

Quick Save/Load support

Widescreen support

Many engine fixes for bugs present in original versions

Translated into 12 new languages: French, Italian, German, Spanish, LATAM Spanish, Brazilian Portuguese, Polish, Russian, Japanese, Korean, Traditional Chinese and Simplified Chinese

¹Original DOS versions of Heretic: Shadow of the Serpent Riders, Hexen: Beyond Heretic and Hexen: Deathkings of the Dark Citadel are included in the Steam version.

² account required.

³Mods need to be installed separately; installation requires additional system storage.

⁵Compatible display required.

About the Included Games
Heretic: Shadow of the Serpent Riders

Three brothers, known as the Serpent Riders, used their powerful magic to possess and corrupt the seven kings of the realm, plunging it into war and chaos. But a race of elves known as the Sidhe resisted and were branded heretics. On the brink of losing the war, the Sidhe elders sacrificed themselves and the elven capital city to destroy the seven kings and their armies. As one of the few surviving elves, you embark on a quest for vengeance against those who slaughtered your friends, family, and entire race.

Heretic: Faith Renewed [NEW]

Years after the planes were cleansed of D'Sparil's wretched influence, a wandering warrior in search of home arrives at a foreign land to discover the blighted stains of that old time religion seeping through the cracks of society once more. In the fortified city, zealous acolytes stand high atop a decadent cathedral and listen to the lamentations echoing from the streets as non-believers are dragged away for 'correction.' The shadow of D'Sparil lingers after death, his absence attributed to apotheosis. Once revered, now worshipped, deserving of neither. An all-too-familiar scene, and one you simply cannot stomach. Taking up the mantle of Heretic once more, you stride into the city, staff in hand, to silence the echoes of your arch-nemesis.

Hexen: Beyond Heretic

While the Sidhe elf Corvus battled the evil forces of D'Sparil, the remaining two Serpent Riders were busy sowing the seeds of destruction in other dimensions. As a Warrior, Mage, or Cleric, you must fight the undead and brave elemental dungeons and decaying wilderness to defend your realm of Cronos from Korax, the second Serpent Rider.

Hexen: Deathkings of the Dark Citadel

After defeating the evil Korax, the second Serpent Rider, and discovering the Chaos Sphere, you have been transported to the Realm of the Dead. Now your only way home is blocked by hordes of undead and the Dark Citadel. Where Hexen ends, the true nightmare begins.

Hexen: Vestiges of Grandeur [NEW]

Powered by

Assassin’s Creed: Mirage

With the series just two months away from its 18th anniversary and Assassin’s Creed: Shadows ’ success, now’s a great time to catch up with Mirage , especially since it’s included in Game Pass. This installment acts as a perfect palate cleanser for fans who miss the classic, stealth-driven Assassin’s Creed formula after years of sprawling RPG entries. It’s shorter, sharper, and is a return to form as it leans hard into parkour, assassinations, and dense urban environments.

The story follows Basim Ibn Ishaq, a familiar face from Assassin’s Creed: Valhalla . Basim is a cunning street thief in 9th-century Baghdad whose life changes after a violent encounter pulls him into the Hidden Ones. As he hones his skills in stealth and subterfuge, Basim’s journey uncovers political intrigue, hidden agendas, and personal revelations that ripple throughout the Assassin’s Creed universe.

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Assassin's Creed: Mirage
Action-Adventure
Systems
8 /10
11
8.3 /10
Released
October 12, 2023
ESRB
m

Ubisoft Bordeaux
Publisher(s)
Ubisoft

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Persona 3 Reload

If anyone has been meaning to play Persona 3 Reload , now’s the time. This beloved JRPG remake is leaving Game Pass soon, and that’s a shame given that Reload is Persona 3 at its sharpest. The updated visuals, quality-of-life tweaks, and soundtrack breathe new life into a title that’s often cited as one of the most emotional entries in the series. It’s an easy recommendation for anyone who enjoys character-driven storytelling, social sim elements, and turn-based combat with depth.

The story follows Yuki Makoto, a transfer student at Gekkoukan High School who stumbles into the Dark Hour, a hidden time between days when Shadows prey on the minds of the living. Alongside the Specialized Extracurricular Execution Squad (SEES), he ascends the mysterious tower Tartarus to uncover the truth, harnessing the power of Personas while forging bonds alongside the squad’s growing strength.

Your comment has not been saved

Persona 3 Reload
JRPG
Systems

M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood, Partial Nudity, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
P-Studio

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 - Cross-Gen Bundle

With Modern Warfare 3 ’s recent updates and multiplayer events, now is a great time to jump in, as the online portion of the game is full of content. The Cross-Gen Bundle gives access to both the campaign and competitive modes, meaning that anyone can experience the cinematic action while sharpening their skills online.

The narrative continues the high-stakes story of Task Force 141, the elite multinational unit battling the ruthless Ultranationalist leader Vladimir Makarov. As Makarov maneuvers to ignite a third world war, players globe-trot through tense missions, infiltrations, and large-scale battles that blur the line between playable cinema and blockbuster spectacle. While the campaign won't be everyone because of its focus on open-combat missions instead of exciting set pieces, everyone looking for a fun shooter should give the multiplayer a try, as its combination of classic MW2 map remakes and a gigantic weapon lineup will provide hours of fun. MWZ is also worth a try, as some players loved the attempt at open-world Zombies.

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 (2023)
First-Person Shooter
Systems
6 /10

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Sledgehammer Games
Publisher(s)
Activision

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle

With QuakeCon wrapping up, there’s no better time to spotlight one of Bethesda’s best adventures in recent memory. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle might not be new to Game Pass, but it’s still a must-play for anyone craving the thrill of discovery and the tension of ancient mysteries. Its mix of traversal, puzzle-solving, and dynamic set-pieces sets it apart from most action-adventure titles on the service.

This time, Indy’s quest centers on the Great Circle, a mysterious network of ancient sites that could hold the key to unimaginable power. The adventure takes players from sun-baked deserts to snow-covered mountaintops, each environment brimming with secrets and hazards. Along the way, Indiana Jones’ whip isn’t just for combat. It’s also a tool for navigation, problem-solving, and uncovering hidden treasures, ensuring the journey feels as tactile as it does cinematic.

item.title: Upcoming Steam Game Is Like Stardew Valley, But With 'Bite-Sized' Days
item.description:
Firefly Village is an upcoming cozy farming simulator inspired by Stardew Valley , which is coming to Steam on August 11, 2025. Steam is already saturated with games that take direct inspiration from Stardew Valley , one of the most successful cozy games ever. However, many of these titles also enhance ConcernedApe's tried-and-true formula along the way by introducing small twists and tweaks.

August has brought a new wave of Stardew Valley -esque games. And fans of the genre already have titles like Everdream Village and Ritual of Raven to check out. However, an upcoming farming sim also looks like something fans of ConcernedApe's work would want to try.

Firefly Village Is a No-Pressure Sim with Bite-Sized Days and Seasons

While many of its mechanics seem to replicate Stardew Valley 's gameplay, Firefly Village tries to leave a mark with a unique twist: shorter days and seasons. The upcoming cozy farm sim available on Steam has 4-minute days and 7-day seasons, allowing crops to grow quickly and reducing the pressure to have overwhelmingly productive days. As developer Josh Koenig Games describes, Firefly Village is a streamlined version of farming simulations. It focuses on letting players progress at their own pace and never worry about challenging daily tasks.

Stardew Valley is indeed one of the biggest games in the cozy sim genre. However, fans may agree it can sometimes feel hustle-oriented. There is simply a lot that can happen in a regular day in Pelican Town. While that's a selling point for Stardew Valley , Firefly Village aims to replace it with relaxing, lazy days. The upcoming sim won't require constant attention to crops and animals, leaving players plenty of time to explore, fish, socialize, and, most importantly, do nothing—except enjoy the passage of time.

Firefly Village has already gained the attention of the genre's fans and has even been featured in Steam's popular upcoming games list. However, it remains to be seen whether it can make a name for itself or will join the ranks of forgotten Stardew Valley -inspired games.

Fortunately for fans, Firefly Village is already playable through a free demo on Steam. However, those wanting to try the complete edition will need to wait until August 11, when the game releases globally. The pricing for Firefly Village hasn't been disclosed yet. But based on its scale as a short indie Steam title, it might retail for a relatively affordable price.

item.title: BioWare Veteran Reveals EA's Main Problem With 'Super Nerdy' Dragon Age
item.description:
EA has historically struggled to view "super nerdy" games like Dragon Age: Origins as something that has serious mainstream potential, according to former BioWare executive producer Mark Darrah. The industry veteran identified this as the key reason why the Dragon Age series has consistently struggled to establish an identity.

Darrah joined BioWare in 1997, two years after the Canadian studio’s founding, starting as a lead programmer. Over the next 24 years, he held various roles, becoming a project director and executive producer after Electronic Arts acquired the company for $775 million in 2007. In December 2020, BioWare announced that Darrah and general manager Casey Hudson were leaving the studio. This was around the time that Dragon Age: The Veilguard was in development as a live-service game code-named "Morrison" after its initial version (Joplin) was canceled.

EA Executives Struggled to See Mainstream Potential in 'Super Nerdy' Games Like Dragon Age: Origins

Reflecting on his time with the company in a new interview with YouTuber MrMattyPlays, Darrah opined that the Dragon Age series has consistently struggled to find backing at Electronic Arts. He noted that the publisher prioritizes mainstream success, and that it often failed to see how the franchise could fit such ambitions. "It has historically been hard for corporate people, people who come from the sports side of the organization, to look at a game like Dragon Age: Origins , which is super nerdy, not very attractive-looking, and say, 'Oh, this is a mainstream game,'" Darrah said. "They don't see it; they look at Mass Effect , they can see it."

Darrah identified this consistent push toward more accessibility and mainstream appeal as the core reason why the series struggled to settle on an identity, both in terms of gameplay and setting. His comments are underlined by the fact that Dragon Age: The Veilguard is a high fantasy ARPG instead of a dark fantasy CRPG like Origins , while The Inquisition 's gameplay loop is significantly different from the other three mainline entries. The Inquisition is also by far the most successful installment in the franchise in terms of mainstream success, with multiple GOTY award wins and 12 million lifetime sales to its name.

Darrah's remarks about EA executives being more bullish on Mass Effect than Dragon Age align with a mid-2025 report from Bloomberg's Jason Schreier, which claimed that Dragon Age: The Veilguard caused infighting at BioWare. The Mass Effect team within the studio, brought in to help push the game over the finish line in 2023, was reportedly given access to greater resources than the Dragon Age team officially in charge of the game, which is said to have caused friction within BioWare. The purported infighting happened years after Darrah left the company.

It has historically been hard for corporate people, people who come from the sports side of the organization, to look at a game like Dragon Age: Origins, which is super-nerdy, not very attractive-looking, and say, 'Oh, this is a mainstream game.' They don’t see it. They look at Mass Effect, they can see it.

Dragon Age: Origins Wasn't Planned to Start a Franchise

In January 2025, EA said that Dragon Age: The Veilguard reached around 1.5 million players in its first two months, noting that it had underperformed expectations. Prospects for another installment now appear slim. Darrah noted that the series itself was never originally intended to exist, as Dragon Age: Origins was conceived as a standalone game. "There's a lot of threads that are cast out [in DA: Origins ] that kind of had to be abandoned because, you know, there could be werewolves all over the world; there might be a civil war happening underground in Orzammar," he explained. "Like there's a bunch of stuff that's just like, was great to put out in a game that you never had to come back to, but then when we did come back to it, you had to sort of recover from that."
